verses.text: And when I came to you, brothers, I did not come with lofty speech or wisdom, declaring to you the testimony of God.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes simplicity and humility in his preaching, preferring the message itself over elaborate rhetoric. This reflects the idea that God's power is revealed through apparent weakness (cf. 2 Corinthians 12:9).

verses.text: For I decided to know nothing among you except Jesus Christ and him crucified.
verses.comment: Paul centers the message of the gospel entirely on the person and saving work of Christ crucified. This focus reveals the heart of apostolic teaching and the centrality of the cross for salvation and Christian life.

verses.text: And I was with you in weakness and in fear and with much trembling.
verses.comment: Paul’s vulnerability highlights how God often works through human frailty. The apostle's openness allows God's Spirit to receive the glory (cf. Acts 18:9; Phil. 2:12).

verses.text: And my message and my preaching did not come with persuasive words of human wisdom, but with demonstration of the Spirit and of power,
verses.comment: The real effectiveness in preaching the gospel comes from the Holy Spirit working in hearts, not from human argument or rhetorical skill. The Spirit has the primary role in making faith come alive.

verses.text: so that your faith might not rest in the wisdom of men but in the power of God.
verses.comment: Here Paul makes clear that genuine faith is rooted in God’s work, not human intellect. Reliance on divine power is a safeguard against pride and error.

verses.text: Yet among the mature we do speak wisdom, although not a wisdom of this world or of the rulers of this age, who are fading away.
verses.comment: Paul acknowledges there is a deeper wisdom in God, accessible to those growing in the faith ('mature'). However, this wisdom is not like earthly philosophy but comes by revelation.

verses.text: But we speak the hidden wisdom of God in a mystery, which God decreed before the ages for our glory.
verses.comment: The mystery refers to God’s eternal plan for salvation, now revealed in Christ (see Ephesians 3:5–6). This predestined wisdom points to God’s foreknowledge and loving purpose.

verses.text: None of the rulers of this age understood this, for if they had, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.
verses.comment: Calling Jesus 'the Lord of glory' reinforces his divinity (see John 17:5; Heb. 1:3). The world's misunderstanding led to the cross, yet God used it for redemption (Acts 2:23).

verses.text: But, as it is written, 'What no eye has seen, nor ear heard, nor the heart of man imagined, what God has prepared for those who love him,'
verses.comment: This verse draws on Isaiah and Psalms to confirm that God’s plans surpass all human expectation; spiritual realities are revealed by God alone (cf. Rom. 8:18; Eph. 3:20).

verses.text: But God has revealed them to us through the Spirit. For the Spirit searches everything, even the depths of God.
verses.comment: God communicates his mysterious wisdom to believers by the Holy Spirit. The Spirit knows the inner life of God, sharing divine knowledge with those who are open.

verses.text: For who knows the thoughts of a person except the spirit of that person which is in him? So also, no one knows the thoughts of God except the Spirit of God.
verses.comment: The analogy points to the Spirit’s unique access to the full mind of God, just as one’s spirit knows oneself. This implies the unity of the Spirit with God, supporting the doctrine of the Trinity (cf. John 14:26).

verses.text: Now we have not received the spirit of the world, but the Spirit who is from God, so that we might understand the things freely given us by God.
verses.comment: Believers receive God's Spirit, not a worldly one. The Spirit enables us to comprehend our spiritual inheritance, paralleling the teaching function of the Spirit (cf. John 16:13–15).

verses.text: And we speak this not in words taught by human wisdom, but in those taught by the Spirit, interpreting spiritual truths with spiritual words.
verses.comment: True understanding and teaching come from the Spirit, not from purely human sources. This points to the role of divinely guided interpretation in Christian teaching and tradition.

verses.text: The natural person does not accept the things of the Spirit of God, for they are foolishness to him, and he cannot understand them, because they are spiritually discerned.
verses.comment: Spiritual truths can only be grasped through the work of the Spirit in the believer’s life. Without grace, spiritual blindness remains (see John 8:43).

verses.text: He who is spiritual judges all things, but he himself is judged by no one.
verses.comment: The person guided by the Spirit can discern rightly but stands above human judgment. This hints at the unique authority given to truly spiritual leaders and the importance of right judgment within the faith community.

verses.text: For 'who has known the mind of the Lord, that he will instruct him?' But we have the mind of Christ.
verses.comment: Quoting Isaiah, Paul shows that true understanding is God-given. By union with Christ, believers share his mind, fostering unity in doctrine, worship, and spiritual life.
